g.text: virtual bool allow_nested_vm_operations() const { return false; }
// You may override skip_thread_oop_barriers to return true if the operation
// does not access thread-private oops (including frames).
virtual bool skip_thread_oop_barriers() const { return false; }
// An operation can either be done inside a safepoint
// or concurrently with Java threads running.
virtual bool evaluate_at_safepoint() const { return true; }

font.div: // Roll all threads forward to a safepoint and suspend them all
// Arms the safepoint, _current_jni_active_count and _waiting_to_block must be set before.
// Will spin until all threads are safe.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 610px; height: 1px; padding-top: 2004px; margin-left: 1256px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 596px; overflow: hidden;

border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: ðŸ”—

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: void SafepointSynchronize::arm_safepoint() {

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // Begin the process of bringing the system to a safepoint.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // Java threads can be in several different states and are

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // stopped by different mechanisms:

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â 1. Running interpreted

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â Â Â When executing branching/returning byte codes interpreter

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â Â Â checks if the poll is armed, if so blocks in SS::block().

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â 2. Running in native code

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â Â Â When returning from the native code, a Java thread must check

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â Â Â the safepoint _state to see if we must block.Â If the

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â Â Â VM thread sees a Java thread in native, it does

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â Â Â not wait for this thread to block.Â The order of the memory

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â Â Â writes and reads of both the safepoint state and the Java

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â Â Â threads state is critical.Â In order to guarantee that the

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â Â Â memory writes are serialized with respect to each other,

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â Â Â the VM thread issues a memory barrier instruction.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â 3. Running compiled Code

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â Â Â Compiled code reads the local polling page that

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â Â Â is set to fault if we are trying to get to a safepoint.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â 4. Blocked

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â Â Â A thread which is blocked will not be allowed to return from the

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â Â Â block condition until the safepoint operation is complete.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â 5. In VM or Transitioning between states

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â Â Â If a Java thread is currently running in the VM or transitioning

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â Â Â between states, the safepointing code will poll the thread state

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â Â Â until the thread blocks itself when it attempts transitions to a

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: //Â Â Â new state or locking a safepoint checked monitor.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // We must never miss a thread with correct safepoint id, so we must make sure we arm

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // the wait barrier for the next safepoint id/counter.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // Arming must be done after resetting _current_jni_active_count, _waiting_to_block.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: _wait_barrier->arm(static_cast<int>(_safepoint_counter + 1));

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: for (JavaThreadIteratorWithHandle jtiwh; JavaThread *cur = jtiwh.next(); ) {

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: // Make sure the threads start polling, it is time to yield.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: SafepointMechanism::arm_local_poll(cur);

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color);
display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 610px; height: 1px; padding-top: 2604px; margin-left: 1256px;

div.div: ðŸ”—
// Threads might read this flag directly, without acquiring the Threads_lock:
static volatile SynchronizeState _state;
// Number of threads we are waiting for to block:
static intÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â _waiting_to_block;
// Counts the number of active critical natives during the safepoint:
static intÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â _current_jni_active_count;
// This counter is used for fast versions of jni_Get<Primitive>Field.
// An even value means there are no ongoing safepoint operations.
// The counter is incremented ONLY at the beginning and end of each
// safepoint.
static volatile uint64_t _safepoint_counter;
// A change in this counter or a change in the result of
// is_at_safepoint() are used by SafepointStateTracker::
// safepoint_state_changed() to determine its answer.
static uint64_t _safepoint_id;
static julongÂ Â Â Â _coalesced_vmop_count;Â Â Â // coalesced vmop count

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 458px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1219px; margin-left: 2462px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;

div.div: ðŸ”—
// Platform independent WaitBarrier API.
// An armed WaitBarrier prevents threads from advancing until the threads are
// woken by calling disarm(). The barrier is armed by setting a non-zero value
// - the tag. When the WaitBarrier is created, a thread is designated the owner
// and is the thread that should arm and disarm the WaitBarrier. In debug builds
// this is enforced.
// Expected Usage:
//Â - Arming thread:
//Â Â Â tag = ...;Â // non-zero value
//Â Â Â barrier.arm(tag);
//Â Â Â <publish tag>
//Â Â Â <work>
//Â Â Â barrier.disarm();
//Â Â - After arm(tag) returns any thread calling wait(tag) will block.
//Â Â - Calling disarm() guarantees any thread calling or that has wait(tag) will
//Â Â Â return. Either they will see the WaitBarrier as disarmed or they will be
//Â Â Â unblocked and eligible to execute again when disarm() returns.
//Â Â - After calling disarm() the barrier is ready to be re-armed with a new tag.
//Â Â Â (may not be re-armed with last used tag)
//Â - Waiting threads
//Â Â Â wait(tag); // don't execute following code unless 'safe'
//Â Â Â <work>
//Â Â - A call to wait(tag) will block if the barrier is armed with the value
//Â Â Â 'tag'; else it will return immediately.
//Â Â - A blocked thread is eligible to execute again once the barrier is
//Â Â Â disarmed when disarm() has been called.
